data.wave_or_subset: IFLS Wave 4 (fielded Nov 2007–Apr 2008); adults over age 45; hypertensive respondents; split by general health status (good vs poor); disease management analysis restricted to previously diagnosed hypertensives
data.access_details: Publicly available dataset; IFLS received IRB approval at RAND and in Indonesia
data.notes: Blood pressure measured three times by trained nurses; first reading dropped, average of the remaining two used. Hypertension defined as systolic >140 or diastolic >90 (WHO standard). Under-diagnosis defined as hypertensive by survey measurement but not previously diagnosed by a doctor. Time and risk preferences elicited via hypothetical lottery questions; respondents categorized into four groups (most to least patient; least to most risk averse). Per capita expenditures (PCE) used as proxy for income. Distance to nearest health center used to proxy access. Potential endogeneity of education and time preferences acknowledged. Probit models estimated and marginal effects reported; age and age squared included; multicollinearity checked (no concern reported).

method.description: The study analyzes how education and individual time preferences relate to asymptomatic disease detection (hypertension under-diagnosis) and disease management among Indonesian adults, using probit models with marginal effects on IFLS Wave 4 data. Analyses are conducted for the full sample and separately for respondents in good versus poor self-reported general health. A secondary analysis examines disease management among previously diagnosed individuals.
steps: Restrict sample to adults aged over 45.
Compute blood pressure status: take three BP readings, drop the first, average the last two; define hypertensive if systolic >140 or diastolic >90.
Construct under-diagnosis outcome: indicator = 1 if hypertensive by survey measurement and not previously diagnosed by a doctor.
Classify general health status (GHS) from self-reports into two groups: good (very/somewhat healthy) and poor (unhealthy/somewhat unhealthy).
Extract education (years of schooling), compute log per capita expenditures (PCE), obtain distance to nearest health center.
Derive risk and time preference categories from the IFLS hypothetical lottery modules (group into four ordered categories).
Estimate probit models (report marginal effects) for under-diagnosis on the full sample and separately by GHS, including covariates and controls (age, age squared, sex).
For disease management, restrict to previously diagnosed hypertensives and construct outcome: indicator = 1 if blood pressure was checked at least once in the prior month.
Estimate probit models (report marginal effects) for disease management on the full and GHS-specific samples with the same covariates and controls.
method.models: Probit regressions with marginal effects reported; separate specifications for full sample and subsamples by general health status
method.outcome_variable: 1) Under-diagnosis indicator (hypertensive by survey but not previously diagnosed); 2) Disease management indicator (blood pressure checked at least once in the prior month among previously diagnosed hypertensives)
method.independent_variables: Years of education; time preference category; risk preference category; log per capita expenditures (PCE); distance to nearest health center; female indicator; age; age squared
method.control_variables: Log PCE; risk preference; distance to health center; sex; age; age squared

results.summary: At the aggregate level, higher education and household resources reduce the probability of under-diagnosis, while greater impatience increases it; women are substantially less likely to be under-diagnosed. However, effects differ by general health: among respondents in good health, education is not significant for detection, while impatience and distance to a health center increase under-diagnosis; among those in poor health, education significantly reduces under-diagnosis, whereas time preference and distance are not significant. For disease management (regular BP monitoring among diagnosed), education increases and impatience decreases the likelihood of good management, with stronger educational effects among those in poor health; household resources matter for those in good health. Risk preferences are generally not significant in these models.

metadata.original_paper_title: Education, individual time preferences, and asymptomatic disease detection
